 money.cnn.com ^ | May 18, 2005: 11:31 AM EDT | staff
 
 NEW YORK (CNN/Money) - Oil prices tumbled below $48 a barrel Wednesday as traders responded to a government report that showed U.S. stockpiles reached their highest level in six years. U.S. light crude for June delivery was down $1.27 at $47.70 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange following the report from the Energy Information Administration. Prices are around $10 lower than the record highs hit in early April. Just before the EIA release, the contract was up about 23 cents at $49.20 a barrel. The Energy Information Administration said Wednesday that crude oil inventories rose by 4.3 million...

That is GREAT news!
 
 But one thing I have learned about the oil industry is that it is two steps forward and one step back. When the price at the pump went over 2.00 a gallon, we were flabergasted! But when we had to pay 2.25 a gallon, 2.00 didn't seem so bad. Often I wonder if it's just a mind game they play.
 
 Your thoughts?
Missouri Mule

That is GREAT news!
 
 But one thing I have learned about the oil industry is that it is two steps forward and one step back. When the price at the pump went over 2.00 a gallon, we were flabergasted! But when we had to pay 2.25 a gallon, 2.00 didn't seem so bad. Often I wonder if it's just a mind game they play.

 I'm not one to pile on the oil companies. Personally, I would like the lowest possible price for gasoline. However, when one considers the exploration, transportation, refinining, transportation of the finished product, marketing, profit for the manufacturer, wholesaler and retailer it seems to me that we are getting a tremendous bargain. The price of milk is about $3.00 and I'm paying about $1.85 for a gallon of gas. I can't complain.
 
 In any event, by historical standards it is cheap. We paid the equivilent of $2.90 in 1981 adjusted for inflation.

 I would venture to say that overall, globally, gasoline is as cheap here as you will find it anywhere.

 BTW, the stock market is also up $125 as of this post. We're all going to hell in a handbasket according to the Chicken Littles here. 
 
 
 Once again, you defeat your own argument due to the fact that you are not bright enough to even understand your argument. With stockpiles being at a 6 year high, oil prices should be at a 6 year low according to your model, where prices are controlled strictly by supply and demand. Why is it not? why is it up only for dollar based countries? You have still failed to answer that question. Symbiote asked it as the last question in the previous thread where you displayed your stupidity:
 
 
Then how do you account for the discrepancy in the change in cost of oil in US dollars vs the cost of oil in Australian, New Zealand or Canadian dollars, or in Euros?

 
 Instead of being at a 6 year low, oil prices are still roughly mirroring dollar decline.
 
 You seem excited at the decline of the Euro, but a decline in the euro is not the same as an increase in the dollar. The Euro has shown some (somewhat rare) independant movement. The dollar is still down against EVERY major currency. Sorry. you can toss out rediculous ignorance all day, but a person has only to look at a long term graph to see the truth. Even with the Euro in decline against the dollar recently (which is widely being viewed as a short term lull), it is still up against the dollar over 45% over the last 5 years. 
 
 Did you see what happened to the dollar earlier this month when evidence pointed to an unpegging of the yuan? The dollar headed to the cellar, right along with treasure prices. That is becuase there is probably not an expert on the planet who failes to recognise that the yuan is helping prop up the dollar, and that China will probably stop buying US treasury notes once the move to a fully convertible currency, which will seriously hamper our borrowing power (not that the treasury department has actually managed to move a full bond issue for years anyway).
 
 Once again, you prove your lack of understanding of even the most basic financial concepts.

 Like I said, it's all relative. I would work 20 hours a week and bring home 18.00 bucks plus all the Dr. Pepper I could drink. My dad made 3.85 cents per hour as a union machinist at Lufkin Foundries. We grew our own vegatables, beef, pork, poultry, and we even had a fresh water stock pond that rendered all the fresh fish we could eat. We had it made. We never even knew we were poor.

Missouri Mule

Like I said, it's all relative. I would work 20 hours a week and bring home 18.00 bucks plus all the Dr. Pepper I could drink. My dad made 3.85 cents per hour as a union machinist at Lufkin Foundries. We grew our own vegatables, beef, pork, poultry, and we even had a fresh water stock pond that rendered all the fresh fish we could eat. We had it made. We never even knew we were poor.

 
 My grandparents lived all their lives in Southeast Missouri where they were sharecroppers. My first job I ever had was while visiting there and picked cotton for 6 cents a pound. They never owned their own home nor bought a new car. A window fan in the '50s was a luxury and I ate many a fried baloney sandwich by coal oil lamp while visiting with them. I never once heard them complain about being poor. I think they thought they were doing just fine. They made it through the Great Depression when they had to eat the bark off of the trees and sometimes had to boil their shoes for food. They moved up the food chain when they had lard sandwiches to eat. My aunt told me recently that when she went to school she had exactly one dress that was washed daily. All of this whining by the socialists and income redistribution advocates gives me a pain in the tailpipe. My late uncle always said that what we needed was another depression to make us see what was truly important. I have often thought he was onto something there.
Missouri Mule

 I remember Coke when it was 5 cents a bottle from one of those machines where you had to move it along these little alleys until you could remove it. My dad used to pull up to a local station and it was always the same, $2 regular and check the oil and tires; full service.

 I really can't see that happening. If anything, I see the opposite. One would have to study the Great Depression to fully understand why it happened and why it took so long to get out. Remember that in those days we didn't have deposit insurance and a monetary system that didn't have a clue what to do and we had a wholly ineffective president. And then there was the craziness of the stock market where it was believed that they had a license to print money. The only thing we can carry away from that experience is that there is no free lunch.
lord tammerlain

 The western world has had depressions every so often 40-80 depending on the exact period of time since the 1200's ( excluding of course non traditional events like the black plague. Just from the late 1700's we have had about six depressions, not all the same in severity of course ( The US could suffer from hyper inflation instead).
Symbiote

There's nothing credible in the claims of "economists" who see depressions occuring on a cyclical, periodic basis, some kind of mechanistic force. There may be sociological factors at work though, which do contribute to some degree of regularity, but I have my doubts.
 
 We have on our hands the conditions for a crisis, but whether that crisis becomes a depression is dependent on our response to it; whether, for example, we have during the crisis a Rooseveltesque megalomaniacal president.
lord tammerlain

There's nothing credible in the claims of "economists" who see depressions occuring on a cyclical, periodic basis, some kind of mechanistic force. There may be sociological factors at work though, which do contribute to some degree of regularity, but I have my doubts.
 
 We have on our hands the conditions for a crisis, but whether that crisis becomes a depression is dependent on our response to it; whether, for example, we have during the crisis a Rooseveltesque megalomaniacal president.

 
 
 Of course not as a mechanistic force, but like the boom and bust cycles of animal population, the credit cycle occurs. Occasionally big boom and a big bust occurs, generally when people feel that we no longer have to worry about such things that we have entered a new "economy".
 
 All it shows is a trend of having depressions at a periodic interval. It does not mean that it will happen, just that it is likely to.
